node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 15, 2021.

node.text:
When it comes to any kind of organization bins (book bins, storage bins, etc.) the high quality ones from @lakeshorelearning have always been my go-to! #ad 

Not only do I love all the bright color options 🌈 but more importantly, those babies are durable! Their bins have withstood years in my classroom, and that’s with lots of hands-on use. The ones pictured here are the Neon Help Yourself Book Bins and the Neon Heavy-Duty Storage Boxes. 

I’ve also shared my favorite top 5 Lakeshore Learning items for classroom organization in a new blog post. The link is in my profile and stories 💕

Lakeshore is having their biggest sale of the year right now too! If you have your eye on anything that’s not already discounted though, make sure to use my coupon code (6392) for 20% off any single non-sale item 😊

Coupon code valid ‪through 9/12/2021 for one-time use in stores or online. Limit one coupon per customer. Not valid on items with shipping restrictions. Other exclusions may apply. Visit bit.ly/3bbUXIj  for details #learnwithlakeshore #sponsored‬

node.text:
On Fridays, I usually like to share a post from someone in the teaching community for #teacherfollowfriday 👩🏻‍🏫💕 But today, I just have to show some love for a mom who is amazingly thoughtful and SO SUPPORTIVE of her kids’ teachers! 💗

@kristensellentin, you have outdone yourself with this back to school gift basket. And your book display too!! 😍 Not only is it beautiful, but you’re helping to foster a love of reading at home for your kids. Teachers appreciate parents like you! 🥰

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Life Between Summers on August 13, 2021 tagging @kristensellentin.
Photo by Life Between Summers on August 13, 2021. May be an image of indoor.
Photo shared by Life Between Summers on August 12, 2021 tagging @officialcricut. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Cricut beginner here! 🙋🏻‍♀️ #ad I’ll be completely honest, I put off learning how to use a Cricut for the longest time…I’m not the quickest learner when it comes to machines, and I always thought it would take me forever to watch tutorials and figure it out. I was also a little intimidated by all of the amazing projects I’ve seen teachers create.
 
Well, now I feel absolutely ridiculous for thinking that way 🙈 You guys…it was SO EASY! I used the Cricut Maker 3, and I decided to dip my toes in the water with something simple. I made some sticker letters for a “Penmanship Prize” that can be used to recognize a student who has been putting extra effort into having neat handwriting. That student gets to use/keep the special pens on their desk all week.  
 
Using Cricut Design Space and Cricut fonts, it was seriously as easy as typing the text and pressing a couple of buttons. I’ve heard that you need a mat for some of the original @officialcricut models, but with the Maker 3 you don’t need one at all! The ease was very similar to just using a regular printer. If I can do it, anyone can do it 😆
 
In case you don’t want to wait as long as I did to hop on the Cricut train (I am now regretting all the time I’ve spent hand cutting bulletin board letters over the years) 🤦🏻‍♀️ I’ve shared an affiliate link for this in my profile and stories!
 
#cricutmade

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 12, 2021.
Photo by Life Between Summers in Central Park, New York. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
“I’ll be there for you…” 🎶 Who loves Friends?? 💜 (or my favorite sort-of-similar show, How I Met Your Mother)? 💛 

We stopped in NYC on our recent trip to the east coast, and took this picture at what we were told was the fountain from the opening credits of Friends. But I came to find out later that it was actually filmed at a studio in Burbank (in my home state of CA) 🤷🏻‍♀️😂 Guess we didn’t need to travel that far! 

Either way, my family and I enjoyed Central Park (no fountain-swimming took place, btw) 😉 #teachertraveltuesday

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
Back to school plans are often jam-packed with team-building activities and ice breakers…which is wonderful! 💛 But class community is also built in those seemingly small interactions with “your people.” Examples:
 
-When kids tell you something about their life outside of school, remembering to ask about it again later (“How was your soccer game?”)

-Giving a student a special nickname (making sure it’s something they like being called, of course). I had a student named Claire who always gave me the biggest grin when I called her Claire Bear.

-If you can’t hug/high-5 etc. right now due to COVID restrictions, coming up with contactless ways to greet each other. An “air” fist-bump, making a heart shape with your hands, etc.
 
These are the simple types of things that teachers do all the time, of course…I’ve always just found it reassuring to remember that building community doesn’t always have to be a grandiose lesson plan! It’s the little everyday things that make kids feel the biggest connection to you 💗

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Life Between Summers on August 06, 2021 tagging @virtualelementaryteachers. May be an image of child and indoor.

node.text:
How cool is this for a recorded reading?? 😍 Cara from @virtualelementaryteachers is a virtual kindergarten teacher who included a read aloud video with the welcome information she sent home for her class 💗

If teaching in person in the classroom, something like this could still be special to share with students! 

What do you like to include with the welcome information you send home at the beginning of the year? Feel free to share ideas with others in the comments 💞 

#teacherfollowfriday #aletterfromyourteacher #firstdayofschoolideas #backtoschoolideas #virtualteaching #virtualteachers #virtualreadaloud #readaloud #teacherreadaloud

Fix it tiCket What classroom expectation do need to work on? Staying Following directions Talking at task and Other: Respecting appropriate focusing on my work others times Why it important to improve this behavior? What will do to fix make it right? StueSgnature Student Signature ※LIFEBetweenSUMMERS Parent Signature'.

node.text:
No matter how amazingly you set your class up for success when it comes to procedures/expectations at the beginning of the year, at some point there are bound to be kiddos who may need a little extra guidance in the behavior department…so it’s good to have a plan for when that happens! ⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀
Fix-It Tickets are a constructive way to encourage self-reflection. Rather than just tell a student what they are doing wrong, it can be more effective to have them be the one to evaluate their own behavior and think about WHY they should work to fix it. ⠀⠀⠀

After they fill this out, it can be used as a jumping off point for discussion when you talk privately with them about how they can make it right. ⠀⠀⠀

These are editable, so you can customize to meet your class’ needs. They’re in my web shop & TpT store, or get them for FREE when you join my email list 😊💌

All the details (and links) are in my blog post about this resource, which is at bit.ly/fixittickets or the link in my profile 💗

node.text:
These student spelling dictionaries have always been one of my must-haves teaching 2nd grade! They’re so useful for kids who are learning how to self-edit their writing. 

On my blog, I’ve shared all kinds of tips on how to best utilize these! The link is in my profile, or you can go to bit.ly/studentspellingdictionaries ✏️

And if you want to have them ready for the new school year, now’s a great time because it’s the last day of the TPT sale! You can get them 25% off with the code BTS21 💛

node.text:
Have you grabbed this book companion yet for Our Class is a Family? Along with my entire TPT store, it’s on sale today! 👏🏼

Just like families have albums at home to treasure their special memories, your class could create their very own Class Family Album. It would be a great extension activity after reading aloud the book. ⠀⠀

After creating it together, you can display the album in your classroom library as a choice for students to read during independent reading time. It’s a triple win...they wrote it, they’re reading it, AND they’re getting those social emotional warm fuzzies because the album’s all about class community. ⠀⠀
⠀⠀
Swipe left to see more of the pages that can go inside. The photo & memory pages can be utilized as a writing center and added to the album throughout the year. If your class creates a mission statement (swipe to the very last slide for an example), there’s also a “Class Family Promise” page where you could include it. ⠀⠀

More details are in my blog post, which includes the link to the resource on TpT 🍏 It’s at bit.ly/classfamilyalbum or you can go to the link in my profile!

node.text:
With all the picture-taking that usually happens on the first day of school, photos can be made more memorable and fun with your class when you throw in some photo props! 
⠀
These ones have sayings for preschool-6th grade. If you’d love to save on photo booth sets for all kinds of holidays during the school year 🎃☃️💘 these are also included in a bundle. There’s a link in my profile, or you can go to bit.ly/schoolphotoprops 📸

node.text:
Do you spotlight a student in your class each week? I’ve always loved how it builds class community and self-esteem 💛

With my classes, I’ve had the Star of the Week decorate a poster that stays up in the classroom all week. They also have special leadership responsibilities, like leading Morning Meeting, calling tables for recess, etc. 
⠀
But the kids’ favorite part (and mine too) has always been on Fridays, when the star student comes to the front of the room and the rest of the class shares compliments about them. Then with those ideas in mind, the class makes a special book for the Star of the Week. 

The star student colors the cover (shown above), and the rest of the class gets a page to write a compliment and illustrate a picture for them (swipe left to see). 

All the pages get put together in a book and the star gets to take it home as a keepsake. The kids LOVE it, and it’s such a simple activity and positive way to end each week! 
⠀
The book covers/writing pages and a parent letter are in my website shop & TpT store ✨
2 versions are available (“Star of the Week” and “Star Student”)

You can visit the link in my profile for more details, or go to bit.ly/staroftheweekbook ⭐️

node.text:
Something sweet on this  #teachertraveltuesday! 🍦 

I love big bucket list travel experiences…like seeing the Eiffel Tower, scuba diving the Great Barrier Reef, etc. But my most recent trip really reminded me how much I also love all those super simple travel moments, like just happily enjoying some ice cream with my girls 💛 (we visited 5 different states on this vacation, and I think we had ice cream in every single one) 🤣

What are some of the little things you’ve enjoyed most this summer?
